title: Sotomayor Works to Build Ties with Trump’s Court Appointees
text:
SANTA FE, N.M.—Justice Sonia Sotomayor said that despite sharp ideological differences with Justices Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh, and the controversy that marred the latter’s confirmation, she was working to build relationships with the Trump appointees that could moderate the Supreme Court’s shift to the right.

On a multimember court, “you learn how to count,” Justice Sotomayor told a judicial conference here Tuesday. “On the Supreme Court, five [makes a majority], and you cannot afford to let personal things interfere with the building of a relationship that will permit you to agree where you can.”

She said she frequently has been asked how she has navigated the arrival last October of Justice Kavanaugh, who a California psychology professor testified had sexually assaulted her when both were in high school. Justice Kavanaugh, who vigorously denied the allegations, was confirmed by a 50-48 Senate vote largely along partisan lines.

“[W]e are all human beings, we all have pasts,” said Justice Sotomayor, an Obama appointee who is by some reckonings the most liberal member of the court. “Now, whether things occurred or didn’t occur, all of that is irrelevant. It is yesterday, today is today and moving forward, I have to work with him. And because I have to work with him, my measure of him has to be what he is doing as a justice now,” she said.

Justice Sotomayor spoke at a conference of judges in the federal judiciary’s 10th Circuit, a six-state region based in the Mountain West that she oversees for the Supreme Court. She drew applause by praising a home-field favorite, Justice Gorsuch, whom President Trump elevated from the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals in 2017.

Seatmates at the court, she and Justice Gorsuch often have been seen chatting amicably or exchanging laughs on the bench. They also have teamed up to promote iCivics, a civics education program originally started under retired Justice Sandra Day O’Connor ’s sponsorship. The two, she said, are slated to do a video together on civics for a judicial conference in October.

“There is common ground in selected areas,” Justice Sotomayor said. “And it’s important not to forget that because those agreements are important in building bridges that help you in the future, perhaps, in slowing things down.”

Both are also authors. Justice Sotomayor has been touring to support her new children’s volume, “Just Ask! Be Different, Be Brave, Be You,” while Justice Gorsuch has been giving interviews about “A Republic, If You Can Keep It,” which presents his views on constitutional principles, judicial methods and the experience of his Supreme Court confirmation.

Justices Kavanaugh and Gorsuch couldn’t immediately be reached for comment.

Justice Sotomayor did offer veiled criticism of her colleagues when an audience member asked if it was problematic that the Supreme Court draws the overwhelming majority of its law clerks from a handful of law schools—those of Harvard, Stanford and Yale universities.

She and Justice Clarence Thomas —both Yale Law graduates—have made particular efforts to recruit law clerks educated at other institutions, Justice Sotomayor said, but she noted that as a whole, the Supreme Court hadn’t confronted how narrow the pipeline to the highest echelon of the legal profession has become.

“Regrettably, we’re nine fiefdoms,” she said, referring to the separate chambers of each justice. “And we don’t interact in the hiring practices of each other. It’s a very sensitive discussion, and one that I don’t believe my colleagues are willing to have as a collective,” she said.
